questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after hitting her head on a metal beam. On examination, the wound has sharp edges but lacks undermining, and tissue bridges are visible. There is no significant underlying soft tissue present between the skin and the skull. What is the most likely type of injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Split laceration Explanation: Split lacerations are commonly seen in areas where the skin is close to bone , such as the scalp, with minimal underlying soft tissue. Although the edges may appear sharp, the presence of tissue bridges confirms the diagnosis of a laceration rather than an incised wound. Types of Laceration Split laceration Avulsion laceration Stretch laceration Tear laceration Cut laceration Types of Laceration Split Laceration (Option B) These occur when skin is crushed between two objects , such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object. Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone , with minimal underlying tissue E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin. Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges , resembling incised wounds. Also known as incised looking laceration . These are not undermined and show tissue bridges. Avulsion (Shearing Laceration) (Option C) Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments. The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying." This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s friction, but one portion is still in continuity with adjacent skin. Lacerations from shearing forces can leave the skin intact while separating the underlying soft tissue from the fascia, resulting in a blood-filled pocket. This type of injury is often observed on the back of the thighs in pedestrians hit by motor vehicles. Incised wounds (Option A) have clean, sharp edges from a cutting instrument. The presence of tissue bridges in this case indicates it is a split laceration rather than a clean cut. Chop wounds (Option D) involve significant tissue damage from extreme pressure. The sharp-edged, localized laceration with minimal underlying tissue damage does not fit the profile of a chop wound.

questions.question: A victim of an attack displays several injuries on the palms, flexor sides of the fingers, and interdigital spaces and are irregular and ragged cuts. Which of the following best describes the nature of these injuries?

options.A: Passive defense injuries sustained while raising arms for protection
options.B: Active defense injuries sustained while attempting to grasp the weapon
options.D: Injuries caused by falling onto a sharp object

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Active defense injuries sustained while attempting to grasp the weapon grasp the weapon to prevent the attack and sustained injuries to the palm and on the fingers which would have been the case with a double-edged weapon. Defence wounds are caused by the immediate and instinctive reaction of the victim to save himself from an attack and are usually seen on the extremities. They are divided into two types: Active defense wounds Passive defense wounds Mechanism of injury The victim tries to grasp the weapon. The victim raises the arms, legs, or hands. Site Depends on the type of weapon. A single-edged weapon causes a single cut on the palm or the bends of fingers or thumb . A double-edged weapon produces cuts on both the palm and fingers . A typical knife defense wound is seen between the base of the thumb and the index finger. Extensor or ulnar surfaces of the forearms, wrists, back of the hands, knuckle. (vs Option A) Rarely on the shin and feet. Arms and posterior aspect of lower limbs and back. Type of Injuries Irregular and ragged cuts due to loosening of skin tension while gripping the knife. Fractures of the carpal bones, metacarpals, and digits (mostly blunt trauma). (vs Option D) Medicolegal importance Defense wounds indicate homicide. They are absent if the victim is: Unconscious Taken by surprise Attacked from the back Under the influence of drugs or alcohol Lacerations from a blunt weapon (Option C) are usually split lacerations when a part of the body gets crushed against a hard surface and causes injury. They have sharp edges (incised-looking laceration) unless much skin is involved and are seen mostly over areas with underlying bony prominences like eyebrows, forehead, etc. Injuries caused by falling onto sharp objects (Option D) can be puncture, penetrating, or perforating wounds, which have clean-cut margins and usually have the dimensions of the weapon causing it.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman was attacked with an axe and suffered a chop wound from it. Which of the following is true about a chop wound?

options.A: The wound is a laceration on the surface and does not involve the underlying bone
options.B: The dimensions of the wound do not correspond to the weapon size
options.C: The margins of the wound are always irregular
options.D: The heel of the axe leaves a deeper wound than the toe of the axe

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The heel of the axe leaves a deeper wound than the toe of the axe Explanation: The lower end or heel of an axe leaves a deeper wound than the upper end or toe of the axe due to the direction of attack and the force of injury being greater at the heel than the toe. Chop wounds/Slash wounds These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force. It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury. Weapons used Hatchet Axe Sword Broad heavy knife Chopper Saber Meat cleaver Features of the wound The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe). It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone. (vs Option A) Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade. (vs Option B) Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs. (vs Option C) Medicolegal importance Most injuries are homicidal. Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries). Rarely suicidal. Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack.

questions.question: An old method of suicide conducted by Japanese samurai warriors as a ritual is shown below. Identify the cause of death in such cases.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sudden cardiac collapse Explanation: The given scenario points to Harakiri, which is a method of suicide done by the victim using a short sword to inflict a single large stab L-shaped wound in the abdomen leading to a sudden drop in intraabdominal pressure and thus causing cardiac collapse and death. Hara-kiri/Seppukku Hara-kiri refers to an unusual method of suicide where the victim inflicts a single large stab wound on the abdomen. It is associated with Japanese samurai warriors. Characteristics of the wound It is a single large stab wound made by the victim by moving the sword across the abdomen (usually left to right) and then turning it up to form an L-shape . Mechanism of injury The wound is made by a short sword while in a sitting position or By falling onto a ceremonial sword. A well-fixed knife can produce a wound like this, but only with enough momentum to do so. Cause of death The large wound leads to the intestines pulling out of the body, which causes a sudden drop in intrabdominal pressure and cardiac return . This leads to sudden cardiac collapse and death . Hypovolemic shock (Option A): this is seen in victims who have lost large volumes of blood causing hypovolemic shock and death. This is not possible here since in Harakiri, the wound is so extensive that the death is sudden due to a drop in intraabdominal pressure and cardiac collapse. Asphyxia (Option B): is seen as the cause of death in cases of hanging where there is a lack of cerebral blood flow and respiratory asphyxia leading to loss of oxygen supply to the brain. Hypoxemia (Option D): this is seen in cases of drowning where the immersion or submersion in a liquid medium leads to hypoxia and acidosis of tissues.

questions.question: Assertion : The appearance and shape of stab wounds are significantly influenced by the orientation of Langer’s lines on the skin. Reason : Stab wounds that are parallel to Langer’s lines tend to be narrow and slit-shaped, while those that cut across the lines may gape due to skin elasticity and the tension created along these lines. Analyze the above statements and answer accordingly.

options.A: Both assertion and reason are correct and the reason is the right explanation
options.B: The assertion is wrong but the reason is correct
options.C: Both assertion and reason are wrong
options.D: The assertion is true but the reason is wrong

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Both assertion and reason are correct and the reason is the right explanation referred to as the cleavage direction, while its linear representation on the skin is known as Langer’s lines. Impact of skin tension: Skin tension and Langer’s lines can change round skin defects into elongated wounds that resemble stab wounds. They can also affect genuine stab wounds, making them appear artificially lengthened. The shape of the wounds also depends on the cleavage lines of Langer. Assessing wound angles: It may be necessary to bring the wound margins together to determine if a wound angle is sharp or blunt. Holding the edges together aids in a clearer evaluation of the angles. Variability in injury presentation: Identical weapons can cause different types of injuries based on their location and orientation on the body, influenced by skin elasticity and the alignment of Langer’s lines. A stab wound parallel to the Langer’s lines appears slit-shaped and narrow A stab wound that cuts through the Langer’s lines transversely will gape.

questions.question: A forensic surgeon is examining multiple stab wounds on a homicide victim. The wounds are wedge-shaped as in the image: Which of the following weapons is likely the cause of the injury here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Single-edged knife Explanation: The wound described in the scenario as well as in the image is a wedge-shaped stab wound which is caused by a single-edged weapon like a knife. The shape of a stab wound depends on the weapon used: Weapon used Shape of wound Single-edged weapon Triangular or wedge-shaped surface wound One side is sharp, and the other is rounded, blunt, or squared off Double-edged

questions.question: A forensic surgeon is examining a stab wound on a victim. Which of the following statement/s is/are true about the dimensions of the wound? 1. Breadth of the wound is equal to the thickness of the weapon. 2. Depth is the greatest dimension of a stab wound. 3. The edges of the wound are clean-cut. 4. The length of the wound is usually slightly less than the width.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 2, 3, and 4 Explanation: Wound description: when describing a stab wound, it’s important to note the length, width, direction, and appearance of the wound's margins and angles. Margins: The edges of the wound are clean-cut (statement 3) and typically show no abrasion or bruising. In cases of full blade penetration, a patterned abrasion or bruising may occur due to the hilt guard striking the skin. The margins are regular, sharp, and well-defined; however, wounds caused by pointed or conical instruments may have lacerated edges. Length: The length of the wound is usually slightly less than the width (statement 4) of the weapon because of skin stretching. Breadth: The breadth is generally greater than the thickness of the blade (statement 1) due to gaping; proper approximation of the edges is necessary for accurate measurement. Depth: Depth is the greatest dimension of a stab wound (statement 2) and corresponds to the length of the weapon entering the body. If the entire length of the weapon penetrates without producing an exit wound, this depth is critical. Safety note: It is unsafe to determine the depth of a stab wound by probing in the emergency room, as this can disturb any loose clot and lead to severe hemorrhage. Probing may also create a false track by passing between fascial planes or within muscles. Depth assessment should be conducted in the operating theater during wound repair. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 201

questions.question: A homicidal case with a stab wound over the abdomen is being examined. The weapon has passed through and through with a larger entry wound and a smaller exit wound. Which type of wound is this classified as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Perforating wound Explanation: The wound in the above scenario is a perforating wound as the weapon has passed through-and-through the body. Stab wound/Punctured wound These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width. Weapons used Knife (most common) Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle) Scissors Screwdrivers Pens Ice picks Forks Types of stab wounds Puncture wound: (Option A) Soft tissues are involved Penetrating wound: (Option C) Enters a body cavity or a viscus Perforating wound: Through-and-through puncture wounds The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other The wound of entry is larger than the exit Significance of the wound dimensions Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin. Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping. Depth , the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation. Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising. Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed Concealed wound (Option D) is a wound that is present in hidden areas of the body like the axilla, nostrils, etc., and is not a through-and-through wound.

questions.question: A forensic pathologist examines a body and notes the following findings. What do these findings suggest?

options.A: The individual experienced a moment of hesitation before the fatal injury.
options.B: The injuries were caused by a blunt object.
options.C: The victim was attacked with a sharp instrument from a distance.
options.D: The wounds are consistent with self-inflicted injuries.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The individual experienced a moment of hesitation before the fatal injury. or fear before inflicting the fatal injury. These small cuts can be indicative of hesitation , often observed in scenarios of self-infliction or in cases where the victim may have struggled before the lethal wound. Hesitation cuts: Hesitation cuts (also known as tentative cuts or trial wounds) are multiple, small, superficial cuts that typically involve only the skin. These cuts are often found at the beginning of a deeper incised wound. Psychological Aspect : They suggest that the individual may have hesitated while gathering the courage to make a decisive cut. Forensic Observation : In cases of homicidal sharp force injuries, multiple superficial, roughly parallel incised wounds may appear on the neck, often adjacent to a single deep, lethal incised wound, particularly

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents for a follow-up appointment after undergoing surgery for an abdominal incision. The physician observes that the wound is beginning to heal, with granulation tissue forming in the wound bed. What is the most likely duration of healing indicated by the presence of vascularized granulation tissue?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2–3 days Explanation: The presence of vascularized granulation tissue is a key indicator of the wound healing process and typically occurs during the 2-3 days post-injury phase. Age of Incised Wound Duration Gross Findings Microscopic Findings Fresh Red with clotted blood. Capillary dilation, neutrophil margination and emigration, reactive changes in histiocytes. 12 hours Margins red, swollen, and adherent; blood and lymph present. Reactive changes in fibroblasts, monocytes in exudate. (Option B) 24 hours Continuous layer of endothelial cells covers surface; scab of the dried clot. Endothelial growth at edges; formation of vascular buds. 2–3 days - Formation of vascularized granulation tissue (Fibroblast activity) (Option C) 4–6 days - Formation of new fibrils. (Option D) 7 days Scar formation. Scar formation. (Option A) Medico-Legal Importance of Incised Wounds Weapon Identification: Suggests a sharp-edged weapon; the appearance can occasionally indicate weapon type, although this is less definitive than with stab wounds. Force Direction: Offers clues about the direction of the applied force. Injury Age Assessment: Aids in determining how long ago the injury occurred. Injury Severity: Typically not life-threatening unless located over major arteries (e.g., wrist or neck), where it could be fatal. Wound Analysis: The position and characteristics of the wound may reveal the manner of injury (e.g., suicide, accident, or homicide). Feature Suicidal cut-throat wounds Homicidal cut-throat wounds Situation Left side of the neck, crossing the front of the throat High, above the thyroid cartilage Both sides of the neck Low, at or below the thyroid cartilage Direction Oblique, above downwards, left to right for right-handed persons Transverse or below upwards Number of Wounds Multiple (20-30), superficial, parallel, merging with main wound Multiple, intersecting at a deep level Edges Ragged due to overlapping superficial incisions Sharp and clean-cut; beveling may be observed Hesitation Cuts Present Absent Wounds in Other Parts May include cuts on wrists, groin, thighs Severe injuries may be present on the head; no wrist wounds Defense Wounds Absent; may have unintentional cuts Present unless the victim was caught unaware Hands May grasp the weapon firmly due to cadaveric spasm Fragments of clothing or hair from the assailant may be grasped Weapon at Site Usually present Typically absent Vessels Carotid artery may escape injury Jugular vein and carotid artery likely cut Blood Stains May show splashing downward on clothes if in front of a mirror Found on both palms from attempts to cover the wound Circumstantial Evidence Usually in quiet places (e.g., bedroom) with possible suicide notes

questions.question: During an autopsy of a 50-year-old male, the forensic pathologist observes a wound shown in the figure. Which of the following is correct regarding this type of wound?

options.A: Shallow at beginning, deeper towards end

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Clean, well-defined edges Explanation: The given image shows an Incised wound with clean and well-defined edges . Incised wounds An incised wound is a clean cut through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, typically longer than it is deep , caused by a sharp-edged instrument like a knife or razor. It results from pressure and friction against the tissue. Wound Structure: Margins: Clean, well-defined edges (Option D) , often everted; may appear inverted with adhered muscle fibers. No contusions or abrasions (Option B) , but may show wrinkling with multiple incisions. No bridging tissue. Width: Greater than the weapon's cutting edge due to tissue retraction. Length: Exceeds width and depth, with no relation to the weapon's edge. Shape: Usually spindle-shaped, with more gaping in the center ; gaping is influenced by the direction of cuts across skin fibers. Hemorrhage: Significant bleeding occurs from cleanly cut vessels. (Option C) Tailing Bevelling Deeper at the beginning due to greater knife pressure (the "head" of the wound). (Option A) Becomes shallower toward the exit. Indicating the cutting direction. A wound created by an obliquely entering blade features a beveled margin on one side, and an undermined area on the other side. Characteristic of sharp weapons Associated with homicidal injuries. Suggest the positions of the assailant and victim .

questions.question: A 32-year-old male was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, the direction of the vehicle's movement can be inferred from the orientation of the skin flap, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely type of injury in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stretch laceration Explanation: Stretch laceration occurs from overstretching of skin, commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents. The presence of a skin flap , irregular tissue tearing , and embedded foreign materials are typical characteristics. Additionally, the skin flap's orientation helps infer the

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of injury due to sharp force?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Laceration Explanation: Laceration results from blunt force trauma rather than sharp force. It leads to irregular, jagged wounds caused by tearing of the tissue. Classification of Mechanical Injuries Blunt Force Injuries Sharp Force Injuries Abrasion: Superficial damage to the skin (scraping, rubbing off the outer layer). Contusion: Bruise caused by blood vessels rupturing under the skin due to impact. Laceration: Irregular tear in the skin or tissue caused by crushing or blunt trauma. Fractures/Dislocations: Breaks or misalignment of bones due to strong blunt impact. Incision: A clean-cut wound where the length is greater than the depth. Stab Wound: A deep wound where the depth is greater than the length. Chop Wound: A deep wound often associated with underlying fractures caused by heavy-bladed tools like an axe. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 133, 134. Parikhs Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th Edition, Page 222.

questions.question: During an autopsy, the forensic pathologist observes an injury on the thigh, which shows irregular edges, bruising, and embedded dirt. On further examination, the deeper tissues show uneven tearing, with visible nerve and blood vessel damage. What type of injury is most consistent with these findings?

options.A: Incised wound caused by a sharp object.
options.B: Laceration caused by blunt force trauma.
options.D: Puncture wound from a sharp object.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Laceration caused by blunt force trauma. Explanation: The irregular edges, bruising, and embedded dirt indicate a laceration resulting from blunt force . Such wounds often show uneven tearing and damage to underlying structures like nerves and blood vessels, consistent with the autopsy findings. Laceration Laceration is the tearing or splitting of the skin, mucous membranes, muscles, or internal organs due to a shearing or crushing force from a blunt impact over a broad area. When blunt force causes severe bruising and damage to deeper tissues, it is referred to as a crush injury . Characteristics Irregular Margins : Ragged, uneven edges with pointed or blunt ends, often showing small tears. Swallow Tails : Tearing at the ends of lacerations, diverging. Bruising : Seen around the wound, more pronounced in areas impacted at an angle or with downward force. Tissue Bridges : Deeper tissues are unevenly torn, leaving nerve, vessel, and connective tissue bridges. Hair Damage : Crushed hair bulbs; hair and skin tags may be embedded in the wound. Hemorrhage : Less severe bleeding as arteries are crushed and torn irregularly , retracting and allowing blood to clot . Soiling : Debris like mud, wood splinters, sand, glass, or hair can become embedded, carrying medico-legal significance. Wound Gaping : Impact from an angle causes tearing on the opposite side and abrasion on the impact side, leading to gaping. Incised wounds (Option A) have clean, smooth edges and do not show the uneven tearing or bruising present in this case. Abrasions (Option C) involve superficial skin damage and typically lack deep tissue involvement and significant bruising. Puncture wounds (Option D) are small and deep, usually causing localized damage without the extensive tearing or irregular margins seen here.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the differences between a bruise and hypostasis? site of injury.

options.A: Bruises are caused by ruptured vessels, but hypostasis from distension of vessels.
options.B: Bruises typically have clearly defined margins, but hypostasis merges with the surrounding area.
options.C: Bruises are often seen in the most dependent parts of the body, but hypostasis is only present at the
options.D: Bruises do not cause elevation of the affected area, while hypostasis may cause swelling.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bruises are caused by ruptured vessels, but hypostasis from distension of vessels deep, whereas hypostasis is due to the distension of vessels that occurs after death. Aspect Bruise Hypostasis/ Postmortem staining Cause (Option A) Ruptured vessels that may be deep or superficial. Distension of vessels with blood in the dermis. Site (Option C) At the site of and surrounding the injury. May appear anywhere in the body. Over extensive areas of the most dependant parts. Appearance (Option D) Swollen. No elevation of the affected area. Epidermis May be abraded. Not abraded. Margins (Option B) Merge with the surrounding area. Clearly defined. Color Different colors according to the age of the bruise. Uniform, bluish-purple. Incision Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues and are firmly clotted. Subcutaneous tissues are deep reddish-black. Blood is seen in blood vessels. Subcutaneous tissues are pale. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 141 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 94

questions.question: A medicolegal case of assault is being examined at the emergency with the following contusions. What is the most likely explanation for the appearance of these bruises?

options.A: Natural bruises due to physical trauma
options.B: Artificial bruising to falsely accuse someone
options.D: Bruising due to pre-existing medical condition

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Artificial bruising to falsely accuse someone Explanation: The scenario here shows a bruise that is dark brown and irregularly shaped with well-defined margins and redness and inflammation of the surrounding tissues that point to artificial bruises. Contusions can be divided as follows: Artificial bruising True bruising (Option A) These are bruises created to make a false charge of assault . They are usually present on accessible parts of the body. They appear dark brown and irregular in shape. Redness and inflammation are seen in the surrounding tissues. Produced by the juice of a marking nut rubbed on the body. Well-defined margins with small vesicles. Itching is present. Other substances used: Plumbago Madar/calotropis Semicardium The cause of true bruising is trauma. They can be located anywhere in the body. They undergo typical color changes. Redness and inflammation are seen on the site. They are usually round with well-defined, diffuse, and irregular margins with no vesicles. They have extravasated blood as content and are not associated with itching. Postmortem

questions.question: A patient with a history of a fall from a bike a day before, comes with the following findings.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Grey Turner’s sign Explanation: The sign here is the Grey Turner’s sign which is the ecchymosis seen over the flank or side of the abdomen due to extensive retroperitoneal hemorrhage which is a type of migratory or ectopic bruise. Gravity shifting of blood (ectopic/migratory bruise): Bruises may appear at sites distant from the actual injury (e.g., black eyes). The blood tracks along fascial planes or between muscle layers, following the path of least resistance, leading to bruising in superficial tissue areas. Therefore, the location of a bruise does not always reflect the site of injury. Grey Turner’s sign: Ecchymosis observed over the flank or side of the abdomen which is indicative of extensive retroperitoneal hemorrhage. This sign typically develops within 24–48 hours. Cullen’s Sign : (Option C) Bluish-black discoloration around the periumbilical area resulting from extensive retroperitoneal or intra-abdominal hemorrhage. Common causes include ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis. Other examples: Spectacle hematoma (Option A) around the eyes after a blunt trauma to the forehead Bruise behind the ear due to basal skull fracture known as Battle sign (Option D) Bruise in thigh due to fractured pelvis Bruise around the knee due to a kick on the calf

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with multiple bruises on his body following a fight. Upon examination, the physician notes a specific pattern of bruising on his back as shown: What is this type of bruise called?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Railway line type Explanation: The above clinical scenario shows patterned contusions that appear as two parallel , linear hemorrhages with normal skin in between known as tram track or railway line-type contusions. Bruises can be divided into three types based on their location: Intradermal bruise: in the immediate subepidermal layer. Made by impact with a patterned object and hemorrhage is sharply defined Subcutaneous bruise: in the subcutaneous tissue. Located often in the fatty layer with blurred edges Caused commonly by a blunt object Deep bruise: deeper into the subcutaneous tissues. Contusions/bruises can be classified into two types based on the way they appear: Ectopic/percolated/migratory bruise Patterned bruise In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site. This is also called percolated or migratory contusion. Examples: Spectacle hematoma (Option B) around the eyes after a blunt trauma to the forehead Bruise behind the ear due to basal skull fracture known as Battle sign (Option A) Bruise in thigh due to fractured pelvis Bruise around knee due to a kick on calf Grey Turner’s sign: Ecchymosis seen over the flank or side of the abdomen due to extensive retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Takes 24-48 hours to develop Cullen’s

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a bruise on her thigh after bumping into a table. The bruise is noted to be blue. Upon further examination, she mentions that she noticed the bruise about a day ago. What is the most likely age of the bruise based on its current color?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Few hours to 3 days Explanation: The above clinical scenario shows a blue-colored bruise that can be considered to be around a few hours to 3 days of age . Methods used to estimate the age of a bruise include: Histological analysis (primarily in postmortem cases) Visual examination of color changes Calorimetry Spectrophotometry The healing of a bruise happens by destroying and removing the extravasated blood. The age of the bruise can be analyzed by its color. The color change rate is different from person to person and even bruise to bruise in the same person. Color of bruise Age of bruise Red (oxygenated blood) Fresh bruise/ 1-2 hours Blue (deoxyhemoglobin) A few hours to 3 days Bluish-black to brown (hemosiderin) 4th day (Option A) Greenish (haematoidin/biliverdin) 5 to 6 days (Option B) Yellow (bilirubin) 7 to 12 days Normal 2 weeks (Option D) Factors affecting the color of bruise: Depth of bleeding Amount of bleeding Environmental lighting Overlying skin color Exceptions: In subconjunctival ecchymoses , the color change is from bright red to yellow and then disappears due to hemoglobin being kept oxygenated by air Meningeal hemorrhages also have a similar color change as to subconjunctival hemorrhages due to the oxygen supply from CSF Healing of bruises is very slow in older people A bruise attained during carbon monoxide poisoning is bright red Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 140 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 194

questions.question: A 75-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a fall. She gives a history of landing on her buttocks, where she has developed bruises. Which factor is NOT likely influencing the formation of her bruises?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Color of skin Explanation: Bruise formation (ecchymosis) after trauma depends on physiological and mechanical factors , but not skin color . Factor Effect Age (Option A ruled out) Older individuals have more fragile blood vessels and thinner skin → easier bruising Gender (Option B ruled out) Women tend to bruise more easily due to hormonal differences and less subcutaneous fat Gravity shifting of blood (Option D ruled out) Blood from injured vessels can track down with gravity, affecting bruise location Color of skin Does not affect bruise formation ; may only influence visual perception of the bruise Skin pigmentation may affect how visible a bruise is (e.g., may appear less prominent on darker skin), but it has no effect on whether a bruise forms . Bruise characteristics such as timing, location, and size are used in forensic and clinical assessments , and depend on internal factors , not skin colour.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between postmortem and antemortem abrasions? reddish-brown to dark brown in color. occur on any part of the body.

options.A: Antemortem abrasions are yellowish-white or pale, whereas postmortem abrasions are
options.B: Postmortem abrasions are typically found on bony prominences, while antemortem abrasions can
options.C: Congestion is definitive of postmortem abrasions.
options.D: Both postmortem and antemortem abrasions exhibit bleeding with clot formation.

questions.explanation: antemortem abrasions can occur on any part of the body. Correct Answer: B) Postmortem abrasions are typically found on bony prominences, while antemortem abrasions can occur on any part of the body. Explanation: Postmortem abrasions are often the result of handling or movement of the body after death, and they typically occur over bony prominences where the skin is easily damaged. In contrast, antemortem abrasions can occur anywhere due to trauma experienced while the person is still alive. Postmortem Abrasion Vs Antemortem Abrasion Feature Postmortem Abrasion Antemortem Abrasion Image Intra-vital reaction or congestion (Option C) Absent Present Site (Option B) Typically found on bony prominences Can occur on any part of the body Color of abrasion (Option A) Yellowish-white or pale Reddish-brown to dark brown Scab formation Absent or minimal Present and well-formed Exudates Less or absent Increased (due to inflammatory reaction) Elevation (Scab) Less raised More raised due to active healing Bleeding/ Color changes (Option D) No active bleeding Active bleeding with clot formation Healing process No healing process Healing starts with inflammation

questions.question: A 35-year-old male is being evaluated for injuries as part of a medico-legal case. During the examination, an abrasion wound is noted to be brown in color. Based on the appearance of the wound, what is the most likely time since the injury occurred?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 4-5 days Explanation: By 4-5 days, the wound has undergone healing processes, and the scab typically appears brown, indicating desiccation and progress in wound healing. Direction of Force in Abrasion and Color of Scab with Time Direction of Force in Abrasion The direction of force applied in an abrasion can be identified based on specific characteristics of the skin damage. At the end of an abrasion, the skin shows distinct features that help determine the direction of the force, particularly through epithelial tags or aggregated lines. Characteristics of the end of an abrasion: Multiple Lines Indicate the endpoint of the abrasion. Reflect the direction of the applied force. Uneven and Longitudinal Lines Show irregularity at the end of the abrasion. Suggest pulling or scraping of the skin. Heaped-up or Aggregated Lines Also known as Epithelial tags (Terminal tags) Skin tissues dragged opposite to the force direction. Point toward the end of the abrasion, indicating the force direction E.g., tags heaped at the right end, if the force was left to right. Color of Scab and Aging of Abrasion A scab forms as blood or lymph exudate dries up on the surface of the abrasion, providing valuable information regarding the age of the injury. The color progression of the scab is indicative of how long the abrasion has been present. Color changes of a scab over time: Time Post-Injury Scab Color Description Before 12 hours No scab Exudate is still fluid and not yet dried. 12-24 hours Bright red Fresh blood and exudate are present. 2-3 days Reddish-brown Scab darkens, indicating it is ageing. 4-5 days Brown Scab continues to darken, turning brown. 6-7 days Black Scab becomes black, marking the late stage of healing. After 7 days Falls off Scab typically falls off after this period.

This differs from superficial abrasions, which do not cause such depth of injury. Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion) Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force (Option D) applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis (Option C) . Features: Deeper skin injuries (Option A) are often seen with prolonged pressure, potentially leading to necrosis. Examples: Ligature marks in hanging or strangulation.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man was involved in a road traffic accident and presented with abrasion marks visible on his body. The abrasion pattern appears consistent with a distinct type of injury mechanism. Based on the image provided, what type of abrasion is most likely in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Imprint Abrasion Explanation: Imprint abrasions occur when a patterned object, like a vehicle tyre or a textured surface, presses against the skin, leaving a distinct impression of the object. In this case, the patterned nature of the injury suggests an imprint abrasion. Abrasion: Abrasion is a superficial injury caused by the removal or damage of the skin's outer layer (epidermis) due to friction or pressure. It is classified into four main types: Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion) (Option A) Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion) (Option B) Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion. Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width. Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion. Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes. Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn. Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows.
